author: sergi sapena
title: Gandia gana 200.000 metros cuadrados de parque en primera línea de playa - Levante-EMV
text: Gandia gana 200.000 metros cuadrados de parque en primera línea de playa El Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica incluye en la zona de dominio público marítimo terrestre la franja de 100 metros en la playa de l’Auir tras un proceso de expropiación iniciado hace veinte años Ahora ya se podrá habilitar el paseo verde y arbolado que el ministerio proyectó hace años sergi sapena El Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica va a culminar en las próximas semanas uno de los mayores regalos que ha hecho a Gandia. Se trata de la adquisición, mediante el procedimiento de expropiación forzosa, de una franja de 100 metros de anchura a lo largo de dos kilómetros en la playa de l’Auir. Así, ese espacio, que suma 200.000 metros cuadrados, se podrá convertir finalmente en un parque público con un paseo con mucho arbolado que irá desde el límite norte urbanizado de la playa de Gandia hasta el cauce del río Vaca, lindando con el término de Xeraco. El proceso ha sido largo. Fue hace veinte años cuando la entonces ministra de Medio Ambiente, Cristina Narbona, anunció la expropiación de las fincas agrícolas situadas inmediatamente detrás de las dunas de l’Auir, una decisión que tuvo que superar muchos obstáculos porque, entre otros aspectos, los propietarios primero se opusieron a ceder el espacio y después discreparon con el valor económico de dicha operación. El propio ministerio, que daba por hecha la adquisición del suelo, anunció entonces que esa franja de terreno se convertiría en un parque público y redactó un proyecto consistente en una actuación de naturaleza «blanda». Es decir, zonas de paseo, árboles que den mucha sombra y pasarelas transversales para permitir a las personas el acceso a la playa sin poner en riesgo las dunas litorales, sometidas a protección ambiental y en las que viven animales y plantas igualmente protegidos. Esa obra, sin embargo, no ha podido ejecutarse porque, por así decirlo, la expropiación no era firme. Ese paso es el que se acaba de dar con el anuncio del Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica de modificar el deslinde en esa zona, trasladando la línea marítimo terrestre cien metros al interior desde las dunas, lo que automáticamente clasifica los 200.000 metros cuadrados de esta franja como zona de dominio público. A esa superficie pública se suma la de las dunas y la playa propiamente dicha, alcanzando alrededor de un kilómetro cuadrado. A partir de este momento el Gobierno podrá acometer las actuaciones previstas para habilitar ese paseo verde que, a su vez, conectará con el que recientemente ha ejecutado el Ayuntamiento de Gandia en la calle de la Ribera Baixa, la que cierra la zona urbana litoral por el norte. Una playa-símbolo En la Safor la playa de l’Auir constituye un símbolo por haber quedado milagrosamente libre de hormigón pese a las distintas épocas de vorágine constructora. La bajísima edificabilidad que le asignó el Plan General de Ordenación Urbana que Gandia aprobó en 1983 la hizo poco atractiva, más aún cuando había suelo de sobra en otras zonas para construir los grandes edificios que ahora se ven, tanto al sur, en Gandia, como al norte, ya en el término de Xeraco. Hace años el Ayuntamiento de Gandia descubrió que ese pequeño paraíso podía explotarse como un recurso turístico único: una playa virgen donde disfrutar de un ecosistema protegido entre el Mediterráneo, el marjal de la Safor y las alturas del macizo montañoso del Mondúver. A preguntas de este periódico, el director general de Medio Natural de Gandia, Daniel Muñoz, mostró su satisfacción por este paso que cierra cualquier intento de construir. Muñoz también confía que en el momento que sea posible el Ministerio busque cómo financiar la zona verde que se proyectó en su día. Eso añadirá un elemento de atracción turística y, al mismo tiempo, preservará este envidiable espacio natural que recuerda aquellas desaparecidas playas sin construcciones. author: George Pohly
title: Romeo romps in MAC Red girls cross country jamboree
text:
The champs are off and running.
Lillian Deskins finished first to help Romeo sweep the first five places as the Bulldogs rolled in the Macomb Area Conference Red Division cross country jamboree Wednesday.
Deskins, a senior, finished in 19:00.3 and Violet Hrabovsky, Annie Hrabovsky, Natalia Guaresimo and Olivia Purdy followed her to the finish line as the defending state Division 1 champions scored the minimum of 15 points at Stony Creek Eastwood Beach.
Related Articles High School Sports | William Puzinsky’s pair of penalty saves preserves Lutheran North’s win over Cranbrook High School Sports | Photo gallery from Bloomfield Hills Cranbrook-Kingswood vs. Lutheran North boys soccer High School Sports | WISE GUY: MAC Red vs. White superiority up for grabs in Week 2 High School Sports | Romeo’s ‘variety’ instrumental in MAC Red win over Anchor Bay High School Sports | LaMilza leads Dakota to first place at MAC Red cross country jamboree “The goal was to work together and help each other through it,” senior Violet Hrabovsky said.
All five Romeo scorers were in the lineup when the Bulldogs won the state meet last November.
“We had a couple people racing for the first time this season,” Guaresimo said, “so we were trying to help them, pick them up as we went along.”
It was the second meet of the season for Romeo. Coach Mike Buslepp’s team won the Early Bird Open at Huron Meadows Metropark on Aug. 29.
“It’s good to know that you feel good and confident at this part of the season so you can finish strong,” Purdy said.
Grace Grupido of Fraser finishes sixth at the MAC Red jamboree at Stony Creek on Wednesday, Sept. 4, 2024. Fraser joined the division this year, moving up from the White. (GEORGE POHLY for MediaNews Group) Romeo’s 2-5 runners bunched together at the finish, crossing the line in a range of 19:19.8 to 19:20.6.
Utica finished second with 67 points. Dakota was third with 82 on a warm and sunny afternoon.
Utica was led by Sophia Aquino and Brooke McFarland, who had respective eighth- and ninth-place times of 19:37.5 and 19:41.5.
Emma Brown, 19:54; Siena Muraszewski, 20:19.4, and Codianne Palczewski, 21:49.0, also scored for the Chieftains.
Lidia Clancy finished in 20:06 to pace Dakota. Aubrey Rizzo, 20:23.6; Julia Timpa, 20:27.9; Mylene Pham, 20:51.2, and Ryann Smitka, 21:07.6, also scored for the Cougars.
Others who finished in the top 21 were Grace Grupido, Fraser, 19:30.5; Emmerson Clor, Romeo, 19:35.9; Ella Goodsell, Romeo, 19:52.1; Reese Rosbolt, Romeo, 19:55.3; Maggie Baginski, Eisenhower, 20:41.4; Katelyn Frazier, Fraser, 20:42.1; Jacalyn Yakel, Eisenhower, 20:42.6, and Alice Foley, Fraser, 20:59.7.
Fraser moved into the Red Division this season, replacing Grosse Pointe South, which went to the White.
The Ramblers finished fourth with 92 points. Eisenhower had 136, St. Clair 154, Grosse Pointe North 191 and Anchor Bay 243 in the only division jamboree of the season. The division meet will be Sept. 19.
Dakota, led by individual winner Lucas LaMilza, won the boys jamboree.

author: A Ragu Raman
title: Guts, guns & a goat: A commander recollects his days and nights at the Kargil war | Chennai News - Times of India
text: This day marks the 25th anniversary of the beginning of Kargil war. The highaltitude war, known as ‘Operation Vijay’ which lasted for nearly three months was one of the epic battles that the Indian Army fought and won in modern times. More than 500 Indian soldiers were martyred in the battle for the peaks which the Pakistani soldiers tried to take control in May 1999. India inflicted heavy losses on the Pakistani side (more than 840 lives, according to an estimate) before recapturing Tiger hill and many other peaks held by Pakistani soldiers by July 26, 1999.Soldiers who fight a war from the front don’t just deal with enemy bombs and bullets. Win or lose, the effects of a war stay with them for long. Retired Lieutenant Colonel Sada S Peter, 57, who fought the Kargil war as a battery commander of Rocket Regiment, shares some poignant, yet untold, stories from the frontline: How his team brought hellfire on Pakistan troops camping on the Tololing peak; how a blood-soiled letter found in a slain Pakistan soldier’s uniform pocket moved him; and how a goat gifted as food for the unit turned their pet; and how he fought nightmares of headless soldiers walking down the Kargil peaks towards him.I was sent to the warfront in the first week of June 1999, and soon we were firing at targets using the Russian made Grad BM21 rocket launchers. Before recapturing the Tololing peak, I was asked to go to a forward outpost to observe, mark the targets and order artillery fire at them. I wrote two letters – one to my father and the other to my young wife. I asked my team to post them in case I didn’t return alive.The forward outpost was on a hillock known as Bhatti Post, named after a Havildar who identified it as a vantage point. Our infantry soldiers from 18 Grenadiers regiment were keeping that post as a launch pad for upcoming battles. They were wary of our small team using the radio communication and observing the peaks. They felt we may give up their position. They fought the battle with a lot of pride.They trusted us only after we showcased our firepower and brought heavy casualties in the enemy camp. The enemy was also showering us with bombs that fell all around us.After one of the artillery attacks, about 30 to 40 people were charging towards us and our snipers shot three or four of them within 800m from our post. That was my closest encounter with the enemy. Then our artillery units brought heavy fire on them.After a few days, we heard the ‘whoosh’ sound of incoming rockets. We hid under rocks, hoping they would go over us and not fall on us. Two dogs and a mule which brought us rations weren’t as lucky – they died in the artillery fire.We had dry rations including kerosene, meat, dal, rice, tea powder and energy bars. Some of the boys from Rajasthan had brought some masala to marinate chicken. It tasted good.Our artillery units fired about 40,000 rounds of ammunition on Tololing and nearby peaks. Captain Goswami (now a brigadier), the forward fire controller with the attacking infantry battalions 18 Grenadiers, 2 Rajputana Rifles and 13 Jammu & Kashmir Rifles, decided to go forward to attack the enemy. We were worried after he went out of radio communication. After a few hours, he radioed in to tell us that we have got back. That was the first major victory in the Kargil war; the other peaks fell one by one soon after.In the 12 days at the post, I was involved in 65 assaults on enemy positions. When I returned from the forward post, I was without a bath for 12 days. My unit members celebrated my return by preparing hot water for my bath and offering me chicken and rum. And we quietly burned the let ters I had written to my dad and wife.Soon, our multi-barrel rocket launchers were moved to target Jubar heights. Here we had a challenge: The peak was at an altitude of 13,000ft and our rockets had a range table of only 10,000ft. Subedar Mrinal K Datta, our gun positioning officer, did a brilliant job by manually adjusting the position for a good trajectory to hit the enemy at the peak. The credit for this should also go to launcher driver Arjun Kumar, troop leader Subedar (later Subedar Major) Arjan Singh, technical assistant Rumel Singh and launcher-incharge Havildar (later promoted as Subedar) Rana.When the infantry went up, they found more dead bodies of enemies. In a few weeks, the war came to an end. Our unit received the honour title ‘Kargil’.When we were recovering bodies of Pak soldiers, a letter found in the left pocket of one of them moved us all. It was written by his child asking for a doll and crayons upon his return.A goat was sent to our unit as ration.But the guy who was about to slaughter it was hit by a shell. Someone said it was a bad omen, and we decided not to kill the animal. It became our pet and lived till 2009.My nightmares started for almost five years after my return from the battlefield. I dreamed of headless soldiers and black liquid flowing out of taps. With support from my family, I came out of it. After 21 years of serving the Army, I took up a job in a corporate.(Peter is among the invitees to the silver jubilee celebrations of Kargil victory in Delhi on June 28).

author: Marissa Blackwood
title: Arsenal’s Title Contender Status in Doubt After Loss to West Ham
text:
Arsenal’s Title Contention in Question After West Ham Loss
Arsenal didn’t look like title contenders in West Ham loss
After falling short last season despite holding an eight-point lead at the beginning of April, the principal challenge this time around for manager Mikel Arteta was evolving the Gunners into a more robust proposition to last the pace.
Defensive Vulnerabilities
Arsenal’s defending was calamitous, leading to both goals, with Gabriel Magalhaes hitting the ball against Oleksandr Zinchenko to give Bowen a chance to pounce. The lack of defensive solidity proved costly for the Gunners.
Lack of Composure in Possession
Wasting chances at one end and conceding another soft goal at the other was a recipe for disaster. Arsenal’s response in possession was troubling, lacking the composure associated with serial title-winners.
Declan Rice’s Struggles
Rice, who had excelled for his new club, endured a tough night and even gave away a penalty in stoppage time. His struggles highlighted Arsenal’s regression despite his summer move, raising questions about the team’s After all strength.

author: @dainikbhaskar
title: दो दिन में स्कूल के 200 बच्चों का किया स्वास्थ्य परीक्षण
text:
Hindi NewsLocalMpBarwaniAnjad- 200 School Children Were Tested For Health In Two Days
दो दिन में स्कूल के 200 बच्चों का किया स्वास्थ्य परीक्षण
- कॉपी लिंक
भास्कर संवाददाता | अंजड़
सामाजिक संस्था ने क्षयरोग उन्मूलन अभियान के तहत शासकीय उत्कृष्ट विद्यालय में दो दिन में 200 बच्चों का स्वास्थ्य परीक्षण किया। संस्था की स्वास्थ्य टीम ने स्कूल पहुंचकर बच्चों की जांच की। टीबी के लक्षणों को लेकर जागरूकता फैलाई। बच्चों और शिक्षकों को टीबी के शुरुआती लक्षण, बचाव के तरीके और समय पर इलाज की जानकारी दी । यह अभियान एसबीआई फाउंडेशन के सहयोग से जिले में चलाया जा रहा है। इसका उद्देश्य जिले को टीबी मुक्त बनाना है। संस्था समुदाय स्तर पर भी लगातार स्वास्थ्य शिविर, जागरूकता सत्र और संदिग्ध मरीजों की पहचान कर उन्हें इलाज की सुविधा दे रही है। संस्था के प्रतिनिधि हर्षा परमार, अनूप मसानी और शुभम चौधरी ने बताया कि आने वाले दिनों में अन्य स्कूलों और समुदायों में भी इसी तरह की गतिविधियां होगी।
पूरी खबर पढ़ें ऐप परप्रीमियम मेंबरशिप है तो
लॉगिन करें

author: Olena Mukhina
title: Russo-Ukrainian war, day 708: Ukraine sinks Russian missile boat in Black Sea
text:
Exclusive
|
|
|
|Ukraine claims milestone in top UN Court, but Russia left unpunished. After nearly 7 years, the International Court of Justice issued a nuanced ruling on Ukraine’s case over Russian violations in occupied Crimea and Donbas – one with symbolic meaning but limited tangible impact for now.
Military
Frontline report: Months of strikes set stage for latest missile onslaught on Crimea. By targeting radars and communications, Ukraine has uncovered flaws in Russia’s network of Crimean defenses, enabling an escalating missile and drone campaign. Azov Commander: Over 900 Mariupol defenders remain in Russian captivity. Denys Prokopenko reveals over 900 Mariupol defenders are still in Russian captivity despite recent prisoner exchanges. ISW: Putin doubles down on vague, expansive territorial goals in Ukraine. However, his goals of a “demilitarized zone” are unattainable as long as there is an independent Ukraine with the ability to fight
Intelligence and technology
Ukraine spy chief plays down Trump risks, requests “sharp increase” in weapons. Unfazed by Russian accusations around the circumstances of an IL-76 airplane disaster right before the POW swap, Ukraine’s spy chief told CNN he foresees the conclusion of Russia’s advances on the battlefield in coming months as he makes a fresh appeal for weapons from Western backers. Ukraine’s surface drones sink Russian Black Sea Fleet’s Ivanovets missile boat. Ukraine reports the successful sinking of the Ivanovets, a Russian missile corvette, in the Black Sea. It’s at least the 17th Russian ship destroyed/damaged during the all-out war. Radar station likely hit in Ukraine strike on Belbek airfield in Russian-occupied Crimea. Early OSINT analysis indicates that a radiolocation station was hit in most likely another Storm Shadow/SCALP strike on Crimea
International
EU fails to agree on €5 billion annual Ukraine military aid fund. The EU will return to the question in March, as proposals have met resistance from Germany and France Reuters: China demands Ukraine remove 14 firms from “int’l sponsors of war” list. Сhina told Ukraine on Thursday to immediately delete over a dozen Chinese companies from a list designating international businesses as “sponsors of war” aiding Russia, Reuters reports. US State Department denies opposition to Ukraine’s NATO membership. In a recent press briefing, Matthew Miller, spokesperson for the US Department of State, addressed assertions that the Biden administration opposes Ukraine’s accession to NATO. EU moves to consolidate €260 billion in frozen Russian assets, paving way for Ukraine’s recovery. The European Union has traced frozen €260 billion in Russian assets, with €210 billion locked in Belgium and Luxembourg, said Deputy Minister of Justice Iryna Mudra. Zelenskyy urges EU leaders to approve billions of Euros for weapons fund. The fund would have an annual budget of approximately €5 billion focused on the joint procurement of weapons and training of Ukrainian troops EU agrees on €50 bn aid for Ukraine after minor compromises with Hungary. After months of wrangling, Hungary backed down from vetoing the crucial package, and an annual veto scenario was avoided
Humanitarian and social impact
Rights official: Russia using fake diagnoses to abduct Ukrainian children. Russia is utilizing at least six methods to forcibly relocate Ukrainian children onto its territory, according to Daria Herasymchuk, Ukraine’s President Commissioner for Children’s Rights and Child Rehabilitation.
Political and legal developments
Armenia ratifies Rome Statute, gains power to arrest Putin on its soil. On 1 February, Armenia officially became the 124th state that joined the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC), granting it the authority to arrest Russian leader Vladimir Putin on its territory. Latvia bans national sports teams from competing with Russian, Belarusian teams. “The main objective of the amendments to the law is to reiterate Latvia’s solidarity with Ukraine and to block any attempts by Russia to legitimize its war crimes through the sports sector,” the Latvian Saeima stated. UK Intel: Russia moves to integrate Wagner Group into National Guard. Rosgvardia is reportedly offering Wagner volunteers six-month contracts for Ukraine and nine-month deals for Africa.
Read the daily review for Wed 31 Jan 2024
here
As of 1 February 2024, the approximate losses of weapons and military equipment of the Russian Armed Forces from the beginning of the invasion to the present day:
-
- Personnel: 386230 (+1000)
- Tanks: 6322 (+12)
- APV: 11773 (+16)
- Artillery systems: 9228 (+33)
- MLRS: 976 (+2)
- Anti-aircraft systems: 663
- Aircraft: 332
- Helicopters: 324
- UAV: 7136 (+36)
- Cruise missiles: 1847 (+1)
- Warships/boats: 23
- Submarines: 1
- Vehicles and fuel tanks: 12267 (+36)

author: ETtech
title: TCS tax demand: TCS employees receive IT demands up to Rs 1.45 lakh; firm asks them to wait - The Economic Times
text:
SECTIONS TCS employees receive IT demands up to Rs 1.45 lakh; firm asks them to wait ETtech Last Updated: Sep 13, 2024, 02:27:00 PM IST Rate Story Follow us Share Font Size Abc Small Abc Medium Abc Large Save Print Comment Synopsis TCS had in an internal memo on Tuesday had said it understood some employees have received income-tax demand notices and that it had taken up the matter with the tax authorities for fast resolution. ETMarkets.com Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) employees have received income-tax demands varying from Rs 50,000 to Rs 1.45 lakh even as the IT major asked them not to pay till the time it gets a clarification from the department, people aware of the development told ET.
The number of employees that received notices could range between a couple of thousands to about 30,000 employees, they said.
Questions mailed to TCS seeking comment did not elicit any response till the time of going to press.
ALSO READ: Got income tax demand notice due to errors in Form 26AS, AIS like TCS employees? How taxpayers can respond to it
People cited above said the company’s HR team in an internal mail has requested employees not to pay taxes till the time the differences are sorted out. According to them, the matter pertains to tax deduction at source ( TDS ) for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2024 .

TCS had in an internal memo on Tuesday had said it understood some employees have received income-tax demand notices and that it had taken up the matter with the tax authorities for fast resolution.

The next day, it told employees that the firm had received clarification from the tax authorities on the matter.
“We understand that the tax authorities will be reprocessing the returns, post which TDS (tax deduction at source) shall be in sync with form 26AS issued by the income-tax department, and Form 16 Part A issued by TCS,” it said. “Associates that received the notice will receive a rectification intimation in due course, and are not required to pay any demand amount. Once the tax authorities send the rectification intimation, the discrepancies should be resolved.”

author: Sentinel Digital Desk
title: Assam: Peace accord signed with United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) - Sentinelassam
text: Assam: Peace accord signed with United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) A tripartite historic peace accord was signed on Friday between the pro-talks faction of the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) and the Central and Assam governments, bringing to an end decades-old insurgency in the northeastern state. STAFF REPORTER GUWAHATI: A tripartite historic peace accord was signed on Friday between the pro-talks faction of the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) and the Central and Assam governments, bringing to an end decades-old insurgency in the northeastern state. Union Home Minister Amit Shah, Assam Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma, and 16 leaders of the pro-talks faction of the [ULFA ](https://www.sentinelassam.com/topheadlines/paresh-baruah-will-support-agreement-hopes-sashadhar-choudhury-683779)headed by Arabinda Rajkhowa were present during the signing of the peace agreement at the Ministry of Home Affairs at North Block in New Delhi. The Union Home Minister said it was a “historic moment” in respect of the peace accord with the ULFA (pro-talks) faction. The Home Minister said that nine peace accords and border agreements took place in the last five years under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. “We will implement every clause of this agreement in a time-bound manner. The Home Ministry will constitute a committee to monitor the execution of the agreement. We will provide a package to the Assam government, besides the approval of several mega schemes for the state under this agreement,” he said. Shah said that 85 percent of the area under AFSPA (Armed Forces Special Power Act) has been withdrawn from Assam. Shah took the opportunity to convey thanks to the ULFA leadership for reposing trust in the governments and coming forward to the negotiation table. “The government has always shown its willingness to enter into a dialogue with a group that is willing to abjure the path of violence and place its demands within the framework of the Constitution,” Shah said. Thanking the Prime Minister and Home Minister for their relentless guidance to Assam in bringing back peace, Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma said after the signing of the agreement, “This agreement will take Assam a few more steps towards development and prosperity. The Centre and the State Government will have to implement the clauses of the agreement jointly.” With this accord, around 8,200 militants, including 726 cadres belonging to the ULFA, have come overground and joined the national mainstream. A host of long-standing political, economic, and social issues concerning Assam, besides providing cultural safeguards and land rights to the indigenous people, have been incorporated into the accord. The hardline faction of the ULFA, led by Paresh Baruah, is not a party to the agreement, as he has rejected the olive branch extended by the government. The Rajkhowa-led ULFA faction began unconditional talks with the Central Government in 2011, despite stiff opposition from the hardline faction led by Paresh Baruah. Formed on April 7, 1979, with the demand for a ‘sovereign [Assam](https://www.sentinelassam.com/north-east-india-news/assam-news)’, the outfit has been involved in subversive activities that eventually led to its banning by the Central Government in 1990. The Rajkhowa faction joined the peace process with the government on September 3, 2011 after an agreement for Suspension of Operations (SoO) was signed between the ULFA, Central and state governments. Also Read: [ Paresh Baruah will support agreement, hopes Sashadhar Choudhury](https://www.sentinelassam.com/topheadlines/paresh-baruah-will-support-agreement-hopes-sashadhar-choudhury-683779) Also Watch:
